data.text:
De Guindos: What we see now is an imported inflation shock due to energy prices. If inflation starts to be more persistent, it can give rise to second round effects. We will be monitoring these factors closely, together with inflation expectations
 
3/3

De Guindos: We believe that inflation is reaching its peak and will decline in the second half of 2022. Still, inflation will remain above our 2% target in the final quarter because of energy prices, commodity prices and supply bottlenecks
 
2/3

🧵 Our rate-hike cycle will depend on the data, Vice-President Luis de Guindos tells @business. There are a lot of variables that we can’t control at the moment but we will act based on how the situation evolves https://t.co/Fn0uM88GHk
 
1/3 https://t.co/XJPJfmiI0M

We are looking for experienced market professionals to join our Banking Supervision Market Contact Group, a forum to discuss relevant banking issues. We particularly welcome expressions of interest from women https://t.co/drtOZTM3J5 https://t.co/cqh8HMox5H
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Andresen, Mr Fernández, Mr Garicano, Mr Urtasun, MEPs, on banking supervision https://t.co/KVJHXASfbu

Results of the ECB Survey of Professional Forecasters for the second quarter of 2022

https://t.co/f80ko0EOiP

President @Lagarde on today’s monetary policy decisions.

We’ve just taken our latest monetary policy decisions, determining what’s needed to achieve stable prices in the euro area. 

Tune into #TheECBPodcast to hear President Christine @Lagarde present the decisions in our press conference 
https://t.co/giO3Ne3zCx

President @Lagarde has just presented our latest monetary policy decisions.

Take a look at those decisions in a short and easy to understand format https://t.co/jfYKjhD4Hb https://t.co/oOtQDoQSN6

Find out more about the ECB Scholarship for Women https://t.co/U0JWSmHU8b

The best thing about the mentorship programme is having someone who bridges the gap between academic education and future career, Tamar tells us.
My mentor has been in my shoes, and as an ECB economist she knows exactly how to prepare me for the career I want to pursue. https://t.co/Nyao2UsAHU

Applications for the ECB Scholarship for Women open on 4 May!
Mentoring by an ECB expert in your field of study is an important part of the programme. Read about Jenny and Tamar’s mentorship experiences ⬇️

Our work affects the 340 million people in the euro area. We are accountable to them via the @Europarl_EN and are transparent in our work:
We explain our actions in hearings, press conferences, publications and more.

Read our explainer on accountability https://t.co/yeM2KZ3xiX https://t.co/cErg9VHGed

We asked 151 banks in the euro area about changes in their lending behaviour and loan demand during the first quarter of 2022. 

Find out the results https://t.co/VvGqxX8PoQ https://t.co/wU2IwWnbgN

Yesterday we kicked off our “quiet” period.
During the seven days leading up to each monetary policy meeting, Governing Council members avoid making comments that may influence monetary policy expectations.
Curious about what’s behind this? See explainer https://t.co/O5F6QUvub5 https://t.co/cErg9VHGed

Panetta: With the digital euro, we want to ensure that Europeans can rely on a currency that combines the efficiency of digital payments with the safety of central bank money

3/3

Panetta: Careful design is crucial for maximising the benefits of central bank digital currencies and managing any unintended consequences.

Research in this field has made important strides and is an essential part of the analysis that will guide policy decisions

2/3

🧵 Central bank digital currencies have potentially far-reaching implications for the monetary and financial system as a whole, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta.

Full speech https://t.co/sXD6ouEhue

1/3 https://t.co/gYJsaNRhha

With our explainers we want to open central banking themes up for everyone. The simple texts, videos and infographics answer questions about topics such as monetary policy, price stability and governance.
Check them out here https://t.co/tGZhpKpifu

Did you miss the @EU_Commission and @ecb joint conference on European financial integration? 
Experts discussed European financial integration, upcoming challenges and the pandemic’s impact on financial sector. 

Watch again here https://t.co/s1JBiP46Sl https://t.co/RxH8Z1KFrt

Panetta: We would not hesitate to tighten policy if supply shocks were to feed into domestic inflation through de-anchored inflation expectations and accelerating wage growth inconsistent with our inflation target and productivity gains. 
But we see no evidence of this today

5/6

Panetta: Faced with an unprecedented sequence of supply shocks and a war that could well bring quarter-on-quarter growth rates into negative territory, a coherent fiscal and monetary policy strategy would also alleviate the cost of reducing inflation

4/6

Panetta: A stronger European fiscal capacity would allow joint financing of such investments. By enabling countries to counter systemic shocks, it would make it easier for fiscal rules to focus on member states’ ability to respond countercyclically to country-specific shocks

3/6

Panetta: The new challenges we are facing remind us of the inception of the European project, when supply management and economic unification were critical to Europe’s security and prosperity. The investment needs are massive but will support EU efficiency and resilience 

2/6

🧵If we are to strengthen our defences, reduce our energy dependence and build a more robust economic base, we will need to take economic integration to the next stage, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta.

Full speech https://t.co/8YS8umhqjb

1/6 https://t.co/j7JNxL9w4c

Watch live today from 12:45 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane participates in a @delphi_forum panel discussion on the current inflation dynamics and the implications for monetary and fiscal policy https://t.co/jQDB9b2XLS https://t.co/5C0Squ0Ucr

Non-banks continue to grow, in particular investment and equity funds.

Read our latest report on the euro area’s financial integration and structure to learn more https://t.co/kTEWWkcAAf

5/5

The NextGenerationEU plan encourages cross-border risk sharing. Together with the capital markets union, it is an opportunity to enhance the integration of public and private equity markets to make our economies greener and more digital

4/5

The economic consequences of the pandemic varied across different euro area countries. The crisis again highlighted the need for better-integrated capital markets to promote the sharing of risks across borders

3/5

The financial fragmentation experienced at the start of the pandemic was short-lived, mainly due to fiscal and monetary support. After being brought back to pre-pandemic levels, financial integration continued to increase, but still needs monitoring

2/5

🧵 Every two years, we look at how the euro area’s financial integration and structure are doing, and at the main changes in financial sector policies. 

See our latest findings below ⬇️ or read the full report on our website https://t.co/kTEWWkcAAf

1/5 https://t.co/2nN8mAgArN

De Guindos: Pushing ahead with initiatives to strengthen the capital market and the banking union, such as progress towards a European deposit insurance scheme, will make Europe more resilient in the face of future crises and allow us to respond quickly

3/3

De Guindos: Recent events have reaffirmed the importance of financial integration. It increases the resilience of our economy and financial sector and improves our ability to take credible actions through close collaboration in EU financial decision-making

2/3

🧵 European integration has come a long way, but we have not yet reached the finish line, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. Current challenges call for decisive joint action to strengthen the financial system and the Economic and Monetary Union https://t.co/anUYkc8Qf6

1/3 https://t.co/dp4ut7h5IS

Watch live at 9:00 CET: the European financial integration conference kicks off with remarks from Vice-President Luis de Guindos and a panel discussion on innovation in Europe’s financial sector, moderated by Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel  https://t.co/av95DFor1q
#EFSIR https://t.co/Ro0mvUvgOA

The energy shock is driving current inflation levels, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @ANT1TV. In March, energy prices were 45% higher than a year ago. But we think inflation will much lower next year and the year after https://t.co/C5AItoXyou https://t.co/Ksw7HeyVtZ

Tune in tomorrow from 9:00 CET to watch the annual @EU_Commission and @ecb joint conference on European financial integration, hosted by ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos and Commissioner @McGuinnessEU.

Watch live https://t.co/Bz7DilhwTg

#EFSIR https://t.co/hVdRYPcRXv

Euro area investors’ holdings of portfolio investment securities issued outside the euro area increased to a record high of €12.9 trillion in 2021, up from €10.8 trillion a year earlier. Find more statistics in our press release https://t.co/DcvxJ9BNcW https://t.co/Aojla3f4GI
Written overview ahead of the exchange of views of the Chair of the Supervisory Board of the ECB with the Eurogroup on 4 April 2022 https://t.co/HPnEFFhG7g

Monetary policy normalisation remains appropriate as inflation is likely to be more persistent, says @Isabel_Schnabel at #Ambrosetti Finance Workshop. An appropriate monetary-fiscal policy mix will protect people’s purchasing power and sustain the recovery https://t.co/534MY3q0jO https://t.co/qFGXvMLwpc
Interview Philip Lane with CNBC Europe https://t.co/J8PKP46scB
Watch live from 13:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane talks to @CNBC about recent inflation developments.

We are looking for female IT experts to join our Information Systems team. Meet us ⬇️ and find out more about the positions we are offering, at our ECB Top Women Tech event on 6 April, from 12:30 to 13:30 CET.
Register today https://t.co/XVKDYlAlro https://t.co/PcFTH2Bt1z

Banks need more releasable capital buffers which they can use in bad times to absorb losses and support the economy. This would make the financial system more resilient.

Read our full response to the @EU_Commission's call for advice https://t.co/qTJu8bSphs https://t.co/VnVuCU5KY1

Applications for the ECB Scholarship for Women open on 4 May 2022.
The scholarship provides grants of €10,000 and a mentoring programme to support women pursuing master’s degrees in economics, statistics, engineering and computing. Find out more https://t.co/U0JWSmHU8b https://t.co/eDAhyK7L79

Watch live from 12:00 CET: Vice-President Luis de Guindos speaks to the @Room4Discussion team at the University of Amsterdam.

Follow the discussion @UvA_Amsterdam https://t.co/OY07SviXRP https://t.co/soligTnA1W

The end of March marks the conclusion of our net asset purchases under the pandemic emergency purchase programme. Chief Economist Philip R. Lane reviews our monetary policy response to the pandemic and discusses current challenges at @PSEinfo https://t.co/wj3Igt4uJF https://t.co/2usXd3K5ka

Watch live from 10:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane speaks at @PSEinfo about our monetary policy response during the pandemic.

Register to follow the event https://t.co/bwDHBkOKJx https://t.co/ObMV26UXnw

Enria: We urge lawmakers to faithfully implement the Basel III reforms, which could be undermined by the cumulative impact of several small adjustments. Our preference would be to apply the output floor at the highest consolidated level in the EU

3/3

Enria: The financial sanctions implemented in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine call for full compliance of banks and other entities. While checking compliance is not in our remit, we closely monitor the impact of sanctions on euro area banks

2/3

🧵 Banks are well prepared for the impact of the war in Ukraine, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria while presenting our Annual Report on supervisory activities to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs

https://t.co/yBMrjiGJkJ
https://t.co/QQB1lfrrmz

1/3 https://t.co/sD2Ia6CFLA

Watch live from 9:00 CET: Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria speaks before the @Europarl_EN Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and answers questions from its members.

Follow the live webcast https://t.co/0juVDMW49t https://t.co/XjEbaM1pV5

Did you miss this? You can still watch Executive Board member Fabio Panetta discussing the progress of the digital euro project at a hearing of the @Europarl_EN’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs

Watch it now https://t.co/eXOwVE8fo2 https://t.co/uks0FPPFce

Panetta: Co-legislators have a key role to play in the discussion on the value-added features that a digital euro could offer. We are also working in close collaboration with the @EU_Commission

Full speech https://t.co/XVYfXtmgpN

5/5

Panetta: People expect a digital euro to guarantee high privacy standards. It would provide people with a level of privacy equal to or higher than that of private digital solutions, and even more privacy could be enabled for lower-value online and offline payments

4/5

Panetta: As important market segments, e-commerce, physical store and person-to-person payments are natural candidates to be prioritised among the possible use cases of a digital euro. A digital euro could also be used for payments between governments and individuals

3/5

Panetta: We want to ensure the digital euro adds value for users and that they have confidence in it. A digital euro could provide a universally accepted and secure solution that facilitates contactless and instant payments 

2/5

A digital euro can only be successful if it meets the payment needs of Europeans, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. Focus groups have provided us with key input for the project.

Mr Panetta’s speech https://t.co/XVYfXtmgpN
Read the report https://t.co/enbOpUWFfl

1/5 https://t.co/euAyFoO24J

Coming up at 16:30 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta to speak about the progress of the digital euro project at a hearing of the @Europarl_EN’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs

Follow live https://t.co/eXOwVE8fo2

Tune in tomorrow at 9:00 CET to watch Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria speak before the @Europarl_EN Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee. Watch live https://t.co/0juVDMW49t https://t.co/1YNZ5L44Ax

Banks have significantly increased their exposure to leveraged transactions despite the pandemic. If they fail to meet our expectations, we will use all the supervisory tools at our disposal, including increasing capital requirements.

Letter to banks https://t.co/mnDS0A7gEX https://t.co/FOEtt5Z8Xc

Europe is entering a difficult phase, says President Christine @Lagarde.

However, with the right policy response, we can lessen the economic damage from the war and manage the high levels of uncertainty we are facing.

Read the full speech https://t.co/YQfd4cM6nQ

Enria/Woods: Supervisors will engage with banks on how they are managing risks from leveraged finance, and will apply capital charges where needed. We will ensure that the lessons of the global financial crisis aren’t forgotten
 
2/2

🧵 Lessons from the global financial crisis about the risks of excessive leverage are being forgotten in some parts of the financial system, say Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria and UK Prudential Regulation Authority CEO Sam Woods
 
Opinion piece https://t.co/R5nNCAyVqZ
 
1/2 https://t.co/5DezKkS58X

Lane: Fading away from inflation doesn’t mean that these high prices will reverse. Europe may have to get used to higher prices. But the momentum element will decline

4/4

Lane: Right now clearly inflation is a huge issue across Europe. But this essentially is an imported inflation shock, it’s a supply shock. Most of this inflation will fade away

3/4

Lane: What we’ve seen in the last number of months is the energy shock, which is by far the dominant factor and which is now further amplified by the war

2/4

🧵 We do think that inflation will decline later this year and will be a lot lower next year and the year after compared with this year, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @PoliticoEurope’s @JohannaTreeck and @suzannelynch1 https://t.co/3KbEryskC7

1/4 https://t.co/JGobMLITOS
Watch live from 13:30 CET: Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul talks to @Bruegel_org about the risks facing banks in the coming years https://t.co/7UbxLPF0XT https://t.co/TmEP6fyqGh

Enria: We did not design the climate stress test and thematic review with the objective of raising capital charges this year. But if banks don’t act soon on the governance and management of these risks, capital charges will naturally be part of our toolbox

3/3

Enria: Against the backdrop of the war of aggression in Ukraine, banks need to ensure that they have strong internal processes and controls in place to avoid any breach of the internationally agreed financial sanctions

2/3

Good corporate citizens contribute not only to society’s sustainability, but to their own as well, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Values can affect a company’s or bank’s earnings and valuations through consumer and investor choices https://t.co/29l1o01mvV

1/3 https://t.co/iAu2n10e0g
Press release: ECB agrees euro liquidity lines with non-euro area central banks until 15 January 2023 https://t.co/Y2x0xQpESW

EU banking rules sometimes give options to supervisors. We have updated our policies on how we exercise the options and discretions introduced by legislative changes. The harmonised policies support a level playing field across the banking union https://t.co/nq7kS55taY https://t.co/UnoyQIjAKg

Yesterday we marked #EarthHour2022 and the lights in our buildings went off to raise awareness of climate change. Interested in what we are planning to do to tackle climate change? 

Check out our climate roadmap https://t.co/03UAPKCPuS

🎥by Lemrich https://t.co/j7wR0r76U8

Lagarde: Our monetary policy decisions and the path of normalisation are entirely data-dependent. Now more than ever, we need optionality in our policy.
 
Read the full interview https://t.co/uKG5uNQnS2
 
4/4

Lagarde: The decisions by EU governments clearly demonstrate their determination to respond to this horrible act of aggression and their solidarity with the people of Ukraine.
 
It is crucial that sanctions are effectively implemented, and we @ecb are doing our part.
 
3/4

Lagarde: The war will likely lower euro area growth and push up inflation in the short term through:

➡️ higher energy and commodity prices
➡️ lower consumer confidence 
➡️ disruptions to international trade
 
2/4

The war is expected to have a considerable impact on the global economy, and especially on the European economy, President Christine @Lagarde tells @philenewscy. The overall impact will very much depend on how long the war lasts.
 
1/4 https://t.co/YxnjUDsB7b

How will the ECB normalise its monetary policy? 

Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel explained to @TiloJung from @JungNaiv the order in which we will normalise our monetary policy and what the war in Ukraine means for it.  

Watch the whole interview https://t.co/q8QLkeSm1N https://t.co/PaXNVyykOl

Follow live today at 11:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane talks about the implications of Russia’s war in Ukraine for the euro area economy at @TheBusinessRTE https://t.co/mBvzQqDDCo https://t.co/Q8IiYhtPAf

The war in Ukraine is first and foremost a human tragedy, but it is also having an economic impact. How is it affecting the euro area economy and how might the situation develop?

Tune in to #TheECBPodcast with economist João Sousa and host @KatieRanger_
https://t.co/2r3GdmnqYm https://t.co/Eq3o7obe2m

Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel spoke with @JungNaiv’s @TiloJung about her career, inflation, the green transition, money, rising housing costs, Bitcoin and much more. 

Watch the whole interview (in German) https://t.co/FqRPq6YGop https://t.co/30CVRw456Z

Fake news alert!

The below video has been highly edited and distorts what our Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel discussed with @TiloJung from @JungNaiv about bitcoin yesterday.

Watch her full remarks on the topic here https://t.co/S4P3cJdfWZ https://t.co/D1B8ubptw6
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in February? How do they compare with January's figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/QfNNRiWdqz https://t.co/RNPm2k3x11

Tune in this evening at 20:00 CET to watch Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel speak with @TiloJung from @JungNaiv (in German). 

Share your questions in the live chat and follow the webcast auf Deutsch here
https://t.co/FqRPq6YGop https://t.co/2XedJzBUOO

🇪🇺🇺🇦 Ми підсвітили Eurotower українськими кольорами, щоб показати нашу підтримку Україні.

ЄЦБ та його Рада підтримують народ України, який зазнає жахливих актів агресії з боку Росії. https://t.co/wqUJaVgU6o

🇪🇺🇺🇦 We have lit up the Eurotower in the Ukrainian colours to show support for the country.

The ECB and its Governing Council stand with the people of Ukraine, who are being subjected to a horrific acts of aggression by Russia. https://t.co/ZZpdjPj1F0
